guide.title: Gentoo Managers' Meeting Summary
guide.subtitle: 12 Jan. 2004
guide.author: Alexander Gabert
Grant Goodyear
guide.abstract:
This meeting began at 1900 UTC, and the guest chair was Alexander Gabert. Although there ended up being essentially no agenda, the meeting was nonetheless informative, wandering from portage issues to hardware. The raw log is available
here.

body.p: Nick Carpaski made an impassioned plea for all Gentoo developers to use our quality management utility "repoman" in order to ensure the high standard of our cvs tree. He also announced that the 2.0.50_pre series of portage trees is under active development and needs testing.

Pappy introduced this issue by asking if "...developers and managers feel we are in need of more bare metal to test releases and software more comfortably?" The simple answer was that yes, we could use more hardware, especially non-x86 hardware. That said, hardware is not the only bottleneck, as it is also often because of a lack of manpower that ebuilds linger in ~arch. It was also pointed out that if portage could handle cross-compiling then life would be much simpler. Right now cross-compiling is not a priority for the portage developers, but if anybody wants to work on it then the portage team would be quite welcoming.

Discussion then turned to what should be done if Gentoo did have more hardware. A reasonable first step would be a compiler farm. The technical details of how to use such a farm, given that root access would probably be needed on those machines (especially for kernel testing), are still rather fuzzy. Pappy will be generating a GLEP to describe how remote access and authentication, perhaps via VPN, can be performed.
